conclusion: The Stirling cycle consists of four processes: A→B: Isothermal expansion, B→C: Constant volume cooling, C→D: Isothermal compression, D→A: Constant volume heating.
In an ideal gas, the average kinetic energy (KE) of molecules is directly proportional to the temperature (T) of the gas, KE ∝ T.

premise: A→B is isothermal, so T_A = T_B.
B→C is constant volume cooling, so T_B > T_C.
C→D is isothermal, so T_C = T_D.
D→A is constant volume heating, so T_A > T_D.
Since KE ∝ T and T_A > T_D.
conclusion: KE at A is greater than KE at D.

premise: In D→A, heat is added at constant volume, increasing temperature from T_D to T_A.
conclusion: The average kinetic energy of the gas molecules increases during D→A.
